text: MATSUI LAUDS HOUSE PASSAGE OF ENERGY & WATER APPROPRIATIONS
label: TITLE

text: BILL
label: BODY

text: MATSUI LAUDS HOUSE PASSAGE OF ENERGY & WATER APPROPRIATIONS BILL
label: BODY

text: Tuesday, May 24, 2005                                                                                                Printable Version (PDF)
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC – Congresswoman Doris O. Matsui (CA-5) made the following floor statement in support of H.R.
label: BODY

text: 2419, the Energy and Water Appropriations Bill, a $29.7 billion bill to fund energy and water programs.  This includes $4.7
label: BODY

text: billion for the Army Corps of Engineers, of which over $38 million has been designated for Sacramento flood control
label: BODY

text: projects including the American River Projects, the South Sacramento County Streams and the Sacramento River Bank
label: BODY

text: Protection.  The funding on the projects is geared to reducing the areas that have not yet achieved the 100- year flood
label: BODY

text: protection level, and ultimately exceed 200-year protection.
label: BODY

text: Click here to view Congresswoman Matsui's floor statement on the Energy & Water Bill
label: BODY

text: “I am pleased that the House approved this bill and that despite overall funding cuts for water projects, the House
label: BODY

text: recognized Sacramento’s flood control needs and our city therefore saw increases in crucial flood control project
label: BODY

text: funding levels,” stated Matsui.  “Additionally, this bill provides the Army Corps of Engineers necessary
label: BODY

text: guidance in efficiently managing projects, with an eye towards long-term planning.  Just as importantly, the Corps is
label: BODY

text: directed to examine its reprogramming of project dollars and specifically identify all funding owed to projects because of
label: BODY

text: reprogramming.”
label: BODY

text: The Online Office of Congresswoman Doris Matsui
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Included in the bill is $38.112 million in funding for key Sacramento flood control projects, reflecting an over 60%
label: BODY

text: increase above FY ’05 levels:
label: BODY

text: • Sacramento River Bank Protection:  $6.3 million
label: BODY

text: • South Sacramento County Streams: $2.852 million
label: BODY

text: • American River Projects (total):  $28.96 million
label: BODY

text: o Common Features:   $1.11 million
label: BODY

text: o Folsom Dam Modifications: $15.85 million
label: BODY

text: o Folsom Dam Mini-Raise: $12 million
label: BODY

text: “I look forward to today’s consideration H.R. 2419, which reflects much thought and long-term planning on
label: BODY

text: behalf of the Appropriations Committee.  This year’s Energy and Water bill means a great deal to my constituents
label: BODY

text: and to my home in Sacramento.
label: BODY

text: “Sacramento’s history has long been intertwined with flood control.  When the city endured a near
label: BODY

text: catastrophic flood in 1986, the community quickly realized they did not have nearly the level of flood protection necessary
label: BODY

text: to fully safe-guard the region.  After the city again faced more floods in 1997, the community set off to achieve 200-year
label: BODY

text: flood protection.  However, until that day arrives, flooding remains a very constant and real threat.  And continued federal
label: BODY

text: assistance plays an important role to attaining that goal.
label: BODY

text: “In spite of years of efforts, Sacramento still remains one of the most flood prone and threatened cities in the
label: BODY

text: country, paling in comparison to the level of protection enjoyed by other river cities.  According to the U. S. Army Corps of
label: BODY

text: Engineers, Sacramento’s flood risk is among the highest of major urban areas in the country.
label: BODY

text: “Located at the confluence of the Sacramento and American Rivers, Sacramento is the hub of a six-county
label: BODY

text: regional economy that provides 800,000 jobs for 1.5 million people. A major flood along the American River would cripple
label: BODY

text: this economy, cause between $7.0 and $16.0 billion in direct property damages and likely result in significant loss of life.
label: BODY

text: The risk of serious flooding, poses an unacceptable threat to the safety and economic well-being of Sacramento and to
label: BODY

text: California’s State Capitol.
label: BODY

text: “With the steady support of Congress, Sacramento has already made good progress towards our initial goal of
label: BODY

text: achieving 100-year flood protection for the region, and ultimately moving as quickly as possible towards 200-year flood
label: BODY

text: protection.  At the beginning of this year FEMA revised its flood maps for the majority of Sacramento to reflect 100-year
label: BODY

text: flood protection.  But this level of flood protection is still a far cry from the protection afforded other large river cities and at
label: BODY

text: least 100,000 people and 1,500 businesses continue to be at high risk in the south Sacramento area
label: BODY

text: The Online Office of Congresswoman Doris Matsui
label: BODY

text: http://www.matsui.house.gov
label: BODY

text: Powered by Joomla!
label: BODY

text: Generated: 27 November, 2008, 00:33
label: BODY

text: “Fortunately, as a result of long bipartisan negotiations Congress has authorized a suite of projects that will
label: BODY

text: achieve 200-year flood protection. Upon completion of the authorized projects to improve area levees, modify the outlets
label: BODY

text: at Folsom Dam and raise Folsom Dam by seven feet, Sacramento will attain its long-term flood control goal.  I deeply
label: BODY

text: appreciate the Appropriations Committee’s commitment to funding these projects to help give Sacramento the
label: BODY

text: level of flood protection that it both needs and deserves.
label: BODY

text: “I am also quite pleased with the work the committee has done to ensure Corps projects are executed in an
label: BODY

text: efficient manner with improved financial management.  For example, the work necessary to achieve 200-year flood
label: BODY

text: protection will take 15 to 20 years to complete.  The committee is asking that the Corp develop a five-year plan and vision
label: BODY

text: for water infrastructure in the country.  The current year-by-year strategy would not be an efficient manner to plan for the
label: BODY

text: significant financial demands.  This would ultimately compromise the ability to implement the region’s flood control
label: BODY

text: projects.  Efforts to comprehensively integrate financial planning and project management in the Corps will greatly benefit
label: BODY

text: not only the execution of the projects, but also the local and State partner’s ability to plan their budget.
label: BODY

text: “It is certainly understandable that no matter how extensive the planning and preparation for a project, that as it
label: BODY

text: moves forward it may get off schedule.  With that in mind, it is certainly helpful for the Corps to be able to reprogram
label: BODY

text: funding to projects that can keep progressing.  But this should only happen if the Corps can return the funding back to the
label: BODY

text: project the funds originally came from.  To not do so, is a complete disregard of Congressional directive.  In such tight
label: BODY

text: financial times, the Corps must curb this practice.
label: BODY

text: “I strongly support the committee directive that the Corps specifically identify all of the funding owed to projects as
label: BODY

text: a result of reprogramming.  I also believe integrating this funding into the Corps Budget, will help clear the books and
label: BODY

text: assist the Corps in efficient project execution and financial management.
label: BODY

text: “By working together, the Congress, the Administration and the Corps of Engineers will be better prepared to
label: BODY

text: ensure limited federal resources are spent efficiently, commitments to local sponsors are honored and projects remain on
label: BODY

text: schedule.
label: BODY

text: “I would also like to take a moment to acknowledge the Committee’s work determining funding priorities for
label: BODY

text: the Department of Energy. This year’s Energy and Water Appropriations bill highlights the Committee’s
label: BODY

text: focus on other long-range issues – noticeably their commitment to nuclear non-proliferation.  Sadly, this
label: BODY

text: president’s go-it-alone approach has been ineffective in reducing the threat. By cooperating and working with our
label: BODY

text: allies and others around the world to bring economic, social and political pressure to bear on any country trying to gain
label: BODY

text: nuclear weapon capabilities.
label: BODY

text: “It is illogical to expect any other nation to listen to Americans speak of non-proliferation when we are developing
label: BODY

text: bunker busting nuclear weapons.  I stand with the Committee’s position to stop nuclear earth penetrator research.
label: BODY

text: The Online Office of Congresswoman Doris Matsui
label: BODY

text: http://www.matsui.house.gov
label: BODY

text: Powered by Joomla!
label: BODY

text: Generated: 27 November, 2008, 00:33
label: BODY

text: Considering the vast amount of nuclear material that is not secured in the former Soviet Union, I believe it is a much
label: BODY

text: better investment to fund the Sustainable Stockpile Initiative.
label: BODY

text: “Through this program, we will be able increase our nation’s security by keeping their Cold War-era nuclear
label: BODY

text: weapons and materials from falling into the hands of terrorist organizations.
label: BODY

text: “My one disappointment with this rule, Mr. Speaker, is that yesterday afternoon the Rules Committee refused to
label: BODY

text: make in order a good amendment offered by Rep. Schwartz of Pennsylvania.  Her amendment would provide the
label: BODY

text: Department of Energy an additional $250 million to accelerate energy research, development, demonstration, and
label: BODY

text: deployment.  This investment will help our nation harness technology to secure greater independence from foreign
label: BODY

text: sources of energy.  As we face rapidly rising prices for crude oil and gasoline at the pump, I believe this issue very timely
label: BODY

text: and of great relevance to our debate today about the funding priorities for the Department of Energy.
label: BODY

text: “This bill moves our country forward on many levels, from improving local water infrastructure to bigger-picture
label: BODY

text: Corps of Engineer financial management and efficiency issues, to global issues like nuclear non-proliferation.  And I
label: BODY

text: strongly support the underlying bill and am pleased it was reported in a bipartisan fashion.”
label: BODY
